expected_chunks: Dear Students, With the publication of the new call for applications for the 2024/2025 academic year, the Lazio region renews its commitment to promoting the right to study. University education is of strategic importance for our region and our country and is fundamental to society’s intellectual and professional growth. The Italian Constitution states that ‘school is open to everyone’ and it is the task of the Republic to remove economic and social obstacles, which, by limiting the freedom and equality of citizens, prevent the full development of the individual. The universal right to education, enshrined in Article 26 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, is one of the pillars of the Republic. Promoting university study also means growing the national economy. Today, universities play a particularly strategic role, not least because of the dynamics inherent in skills training and knowledge development, which are decisive factors in an advanced, industrialised country such as ours. For all these reasons, we are committed to making the university system more attractive and to supporting as many students as possible who wish to further their education at a university in our region. Facilitating access to and the exercise of this right through support measures, and activating adequate economic support and providing welcome areas are tasks that the writer is called upon to honour with the greatest commitment. In pursuit of these objectives, we want to continue the path of fruitful cooperation and discussion already under way with student representatives, with the common aim of improving and implementing services that allow for the right to study to be exercised in full. In consideration of the comments and proposals in our meeting, we have, for example, reduced the amount required for the security deposit, focusing on the responsible management of a common good. We have also increased to 10% the rise in the scholarship recognised by Ministerial Decree 1320/2021 for students with disability grade of at least 66%, or with a recognised disability under Article 3, paragraph 3 of Law 104/92. Furthermore, as of the 2024/2025 academic year, the scholarship will be paid partly through a monetary payment and partly through services, simultaneously granting, regardless of the status of the Beneficiary or Eligible Non-Recipient, a free daily meal for 10 months, to be consumed at DiSCo canteens. Nevertheless, it will be possible to monetise the fee in services in the event that the student is enrolled in a course taking place in Rome, or in a municipality of the Lazio region where the canteens are not managed by DiSCo. We are certain, however, that we can still improve the services offered: our hope is that the opportunities offered by the new call for applications will help many young people to study at our region's universities and achieve the desired results. Dear students, always remember that study is the only tool we have to climb over the wall of ignorance. Education means independence, freedom of thought and the ability to exchange views with others. With this in mind, and as Albert Einstein once said, never consider study as a duty, but as an enviable opportunity. Hon. Prof. Luisa Regimenti Councillor for the University Dear Students, In 2024 DiSCo once again continues its efforts to improve its services and to streamline the procedures for participation in the call for applications for the right to study, so as to guarantee this right to as many students as possible. This is a concrete commitment by DiSCo, which, thanks also to the use of resources from the National Recovery and Resilience Plan and the European Social Fund, made it possible to award more than 35,000 scholarships last year alone, thereby eliminating the figure of the Eligible Non- Recipient. Such results are the fruit of the commitment of those who have worked on the procedures for planning, designing, executing and reporting on scholarships, the main instrument through which the ‘right to study’ has come about. A right that, as now recognised, is little more than a century old with its current meaning and with the responsibilities of the state in this area. A right where today, and more so than in the past, language must be used that, whilst remaining within the framework of legal terminology, is in step with the times. Using language as a starting point, it is possible to reconstruct, for instance, the history of the scholarship institution. A history that goes back to the Middle Ages where one could find initiatives for the ‘outsider students and their stay’. As you can see, already from the words used (‘outsider’) it is clear how distant the current set-up is from the historical one. Compared to other European countries, Italy was late in providing benefits to deserving and needy students. Even in the 19th century, there was a belief that it was not the state, but ‘society’ that should take care of education and the organisation of the school system. The era of university being seen as an elitist institution now seems ancient history. Again, the language used indicates the signs of time. Just think that it was not until the 1920s and 1930s that the 'Opere universitarie' and 'Casse scolastiche’ came into being. Here we come to the rules found in the Constitution of the Italian Republic, where we find the roots of the right to university study as we know them today. In fact, the second paragraph of Article 3 entrusts the Republic with the task of removing economic and social obstacles that, by effectively limiting the freedom and equality of citizens, prevent the full development of the individual and the participation of all workers in the political, economic and social organisation of the country. Article 34, paragraphs 3 and 4, provides that the able and deserving, even if deprived of means, have the right to attain the highest levels of education and states that the Republic must render this right effective through scholarships and family allowances, as well as other provisions to be allotted via a competitive exam. This story is the starting point and premise for the call for applications for the 2024/2025 academic year, which is largely in line with the previous academic year, but there are some significant elements of diversification and further initiatives to improve communication.  Similar to what has already been implemented by the main bodies for the right to university studies for some time, as of the academic year 2024/2025, the scholarship will be paid to you partly through a monetary payment and partly through services, simultaneously granting, regardless of your status as a Beneficiary or Eligible Non- Recipient, a free daily meal for 10 months, to be consumed at DiSCo canteens. Nevertheless, it will be possible to monetise the fee in services in the event that the student is enrolled in a course taking place in Rome, or in a municipality of the Lazio region where the canteens are not managed by DiSCo;  Although the rules for participation have not substantially changed, should the student apply for accommodation, they must pay special attention to complying with the deadlines outlined in the call for applications. In order to be able to anticipate the allocation of accommodation places, the deadlines by which students applying for accommodation must finalise their competition position have been brought forward;  In order to facilitate access to accommodation places, accepting the Council's proposals, the security deposit amount has been reduced, focusing on the responsible management of a common good;  The call for applications includes the revaluation of the cost of accommodation services related to university residences, adjusting the amounts in compliance with current regulations and differentiating it according to the characteristics of the structure, especially in relation to the usability of the cafeteria service,  Exercising a power provided for by law, DiSCo raised to 10% the scholarship increase recognised by Ministerial Decree 1320/2021 in favour of students with a disability of at least 66% or with a recognised handicap pursuant to Article 3 paragraph 3 of Law 104/92. As every year, you are asked to read the notice and carefully fill in the online application, and to this end, a series of guides have been prepared which are available at www.laziodisco.it, the website dedicated to of the call for applications. This is a support tool to help prevent errors during the completion of the application that may deprive the student of an opportunity such as a scholarship or an accommodation place. As resources are not unlimited, these are all useful tools for exercising a right that is provided for those who want to access a first academic degree (unfortunately, it is not possible to finance a second degree of the same grade, even if acquired abroad). In summary, DiSCo continues in its efforts to simplify procedures and improve the language; nevertheless, this cannot take the place of the traditional but heartfelt wish for success with your studies. expected_chunks: Dear Students, With the publication of the new call for applications for the 2024/2025 academic year, the Lazio region renews its commitment to promoting the right to study. University education is of strategic importance for our region and our country and is fundamental to society’s intellectual and professional growth. The Italian Constitution states that ‘school is open to everyone’ and it is the task of the Republic to remove economic and social obstacles, which, by limiting the freedom and equality of citizens, prevent the full development of the individual. The universal right to education, enshrined in Article 26 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, is one of the pillars of the Republic. Promoting university study also means growing the national economy. Today, universities play a particularly strategic role, not least because of the dynamics inherent in skills training and knowledge development, which are decisive factors in an advanced, industrialised country such as ours. For all these reasons, we are committed to making the university system more attractive and to supporting as many students as possible who wish to further their education at a university in our region. Facilitating access to and the exercise of this right through support measures, and activating adequate economic support and providing welcome areas are tasks that the writer is called upon to honour with the greatest commitment. In pursuit of these objectives, we want to continue the path of fruitful cooperation and discussion already under way with student representatives, with the common aim of improving and implementing services that allow for the right to study to be exercised in full. In consideration of the comments and proposals in our meeting, we have, for example, reduced the amount required for the security deposit, focusing on the responsible management of a common good. We have also increased to 10% the rise in the scholarship recognised by Ministerial Decree 1320/2021 for students with disability grade of at least 66%, or with a recognised disability under Article 3, paragraph 3 of Law 104/92. Furthermore, as of the 2024/2025 academic year, the scholarship will be paid partly through a monetary payment and partly through services, simultaneously granting, regardless of the status of the Beneficiary or Eligible Non-Recipient, a free daily meal for 10 months, to be consumed at DiSCo canteens. Nevertheless, it will be possible to monetise the fee in services in the event that the student is enrolled in a course taking place in Rome, or in a municipality of the Lazio region where the canteens are not managed by DiSCo. We are certain, however, that we can still improve the services offered: our hope is that the opportunities offered by the new call for applications will help many young people to study at our region's universities and achieve the desired results. Dear students, always remember that study is the only tool we have to climb over the wall of ignorance. Education means independence, freedom of thought and the ability to exchange views with others. With this in mind, and as Albert Einstein once said, never consider study as a duty, but as an enviable opportunity. Hon. Prof. Luisa Regimenti Councillor for the University Dear Students, In 2024 DiSCo once again continues its efforts to improve its services and to streamline the procedures for participation in the call for applications for the right to study, so as to guarantee this right to as many students as possible. This is a concrete commitment by DiSCo, which, thanks also to the use of resources from the National Recovery and Resilience Plan and the European Social Fund, made it possible to award more than 35,000 scholarships last year alone, thereby eliminating the figure of the Eligible Non- Recipient. Such results are the fruit of the commitment of those who have worked on the procedures for planning, designing, executing and reporting on scholarships, the main instrument through which the ‘right to study’ has come about. A right that, as now recognised, is little more than a century old with its current meaning and with the responsibilities of the state in this area. A right where today, and more so than in the past, language must be used that, whilst remaining within the framework of legal terminology, is in step with the times. Using language as a starting point, it is possible to reconstruct, for instance, the history of the scholarship institution. A history that goes back to the Middle Ages where one could find initiatives for the ‘outsider students and their stay’. As you can see, already from the words used (‘outsider’) it is clear how distant the current set-up is from the historical one. Compared to other European countries, Italy was late in providing benefits to deserving and needy students. Even in the 19th century, there was a belief that it was not the state, but ‘society’ that should take care of education and the organisation of the school system. The era of university being seen as an elitist institution now seems ancient history. Again, the language used indicates the signs of time. Just think that it was not until the 1920s and 1930s that the 'Opere universitarie' and 'Casse scolastiche’ came into being. Here we come to the rules found in the Constitution of the Italian Republic, where we find the roots of the right to university study as we know them today. In fact, the second paragraph of Article 3 entrusts the Republic with the task of removing economic and social obstacles that, by effectively limiting the freedom and equality of citizens, prevent the full development of the individual and the participation of all workers in the political, economic and social organisation of the country. Article 34, paragraphs 3 and 4, provides that the able and deserving, even if deprived of means, have the right to attain the highest levels of education and states that the Republic must render this right effective through scholarships and family allowances, as well as other provisions to be allotted via a competitive exam. This story is the starting point and premise for the call for applications for the 2024/2025 academic year, which is largely in line with the previous academic year, but there are some significant elements of diversification and further initiatives to improve communication.  Similar to what has already been implemented by the main bodies for the right to university studies for some time, as of the academic year 2024/2025, the scholarship will be paid to you partly through a monetary payment and partly through services, simultaneously granting, regardless of your status as a Beneficiary or Eligible Non- Recipient, a free daily meal for 10 months, to be consumed at DiSCo canteens. Nevertheless, it will be possible to monetise the fee in services in the event that the student is enrolled in a course taking place in Rome, or in a municipality of the Lazio region where the canteens are not managed by DiSCo;  Although the rules for participation have not substantially changed, should the student apply for accommodation, they must pay special attention to complying with the deadlines outlined in the call for applications. In order to be able to anticipate the allocation of accommodation places, the deadlines by which students applying for accommodation must finalise their competition position have been brought forward;  In order to facilitate access to accommodation places, accepting the Council's proposals, the security deposit amount has been reduced, focusing on the responsible management of a common good;  The call for applications includes the revaluation of the cost of accommodation services related to university residences, adjusting the amounts in compliance with current regulations and differentiating it according to the characteristics of the structure, especially in relation to the usability of the cafeteria service,  Exercising a power provided for by law, DiSCo raised to 10% the scholarship increase recognised by Ministerial Decree 1320/2021 in favour of students with a disability of at least 66% or with a recognised handicap pursuant to Article 3 paragraph 3 of Law 104/92. As every year, you are asked to read the notice and carefully fill in the online application, and to this end, a series of guides have been prepared which are available at www.laziodisco.it, the website dedicated to of the call for applications. This is a support tool to help prevent errors during the completion of the application that may deprive the student of an opportunity such as a scholarship or an accommodation place. As resources are not unlimited, these are all useful tools for exercising a right that is provided for those who want to access a first academic degree (unfortunately, it is not possible to finance a second degree of the same grade, even if acquired abroad). In summary, DiSCo continues in its efforts to simplify procedures and improve the language; nevertheless, this cannot take the place of the traditional but heartfelt wish for success with your studies. Instead, because we have only two directions to deal with, let’s use the values 1 and −1, and switch between them each time the fleet changes direction. For example, it’s a lot of work to shoot down every alien on the screen multiple times to test whether your code responds to an empty fleet correctly. To make a new fleet of aliens appear after a fleet has been destroyed, we first check whether the aliens group is empty. If it is, we make a call to _create_fleet(). We’ll perform this check at the end of _update_bullets(), because that’s where individual aliens are destroyed.
